title: Monte Carlo Simulation Basics
text:
Key Idea:
Use repeated random sampling to approximate distributions, uncertainty, or expected value where analytic solutions are hard or impossible.

title: About
text:
I’m Mmit Reklaw. I work at the intersection of climate risk, (re)insurance, and data-driven modelling.
This site is a public lab notebook for the Re:current project: small, composable models; clean notes; reproducible code.
Focus areas: hazard analytics, parametric triggers, time-series, energy–water systems, serious games.
Elsewhere: GitHub

title: Contact / CV
text:
Email: hello@recurrentanalytics.com
GitHub: https://github.com/recurrentanalytics
Location: DE


Short CV

Climate / risk analytics, consulting & public-sector work.
Building Re:current — an open lab for climate modelling and decision tools.

Download full CV (PDF): add later
Code

Overview
A Quarto-based static website for climate risk, models, and analytics. The site serves as a lab notebook with notes, projects, models, and reading materials.

Project Structure

_site/ - Built static HTML output (served in production)
*.qmd - Quarto markdown source files
notes/, models/, projects/, reading/ - Content sections
_quarto.yml - Quarto configuration
styles.scss - Custom styling with Quarto SCSS layer syntax
environment.yml - Conda environment for local development (Python dependencies for notebooks)
server.py - Simple Python HTTP server for serving static files

Running the Site
The workflow “Serve Website” runs python server.py which serves the _site directory on port 5000.

Building the Site
To rebuild after making changes to .qmd files:
quarto render

Features

Yin-Yang Manifesto: Single box on homepage with toggle switch (index.qmd)

One container with “Manifesto | Anti” toggle in header
Click toggle to swap between Manifesto and Anti-Manifesto text
Theme-aware: Light mode defaults to Manifesto, dark mode to Anti-Manifesto
Content swaps in-place (not nested, not side-by-side)

Dark/Light Theme: Toggle via theme switcher in navbar
RSS Feed: Available at notes/index.xml

Deployment
Configured for static deployment serving the _site directory.

title: ERA5 rainfall — minimal notebook
text:
~{python} print(“Hello from Python — if you don’t see this line below, execution didn’t run.”)~
~~~{python} import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
lat = np.linspace(-60, 60, 121) lon = np.linspace(-180, 180, 361) data = np.random.gamma(2, 1, (len(lat), len(lon)))
plt.figure() plt.imshow(data, extent=[lon.min(), lon.max(), lat.min(), lat.max()], origin=“lower”) plt.title(“Synthetic ERA5-like rainfall map”) plt.xlabel(“Longitude”); plt.ylabel(“Latitude”) plt.show() ~~~

Manifesto
This site is a working notebook. I use it to think in public about climate risk, hazards, and systems under stress.
Anti-Manifesto
This site is not a portfolio. It does not claim to have answers.





Start here

Projects: packaged work, demos, slides → projects/
Models & Tools: code and notebooks (ERA5, triggers, Monte Carlo) → models/
Tipping Points: strategic card game on climate–politics → tipping-points/
About & Contact: who/what/why → about · contact / cv

title: Hello, Lab
text:
First check-in. The lab notebook is live.
Use this space for short, source-controlled notes.

title: Saharan Air Layer (SAL)
text:
Key Insight:
A hot, dry, dust-laden air mass moving off North Africa that can suppress Atlantic hurricane formation by increasing vertical wind shear and stabilizing the atmosphere.

title: Saharan Air Layer (SAL)
text:
Core Effects

Dry air entrainment → disrupts convection
Increased shear → weakens cyclone organization
Dust aerosols → affect radiation balance & SST

title: Saharan Air Layer (SAL)
text:
Visual Mental Model
SAL = “giant desiccating lid” over the Atlantic basin
